headline.main: The Doctors Said Strike 1, and Schilling Acted

docs.abstract: Curt Schilling, Philadelphia Phillies pitcher, discusses his decision to give up chewing tobacco, interview; was screened for oral cancer along with 140 other baseball players who volunteered to be tested by Dr John C Greene, who recommended biopsies for 15; Schilling is only player to announce result of biopsy, which found pre-cancerous cells; Joe Garagiola, head of screening program, hopes Schilling's decision will spur other players to stop; photo (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: A 15-year-old Curt Schilling was devouring lunch at Shadow Mountain High School in Phoenix one afternoon when a friend dared him to try some smokeless tobacco for dessert. Schilling was a fastball-pumping pitcher and a maverick, so the challenge was really no challenge. Of course he would do it. Schilling dipped his fingers into the moist tin of tobacco, placed some between his gums and lower lip and felt that dizzying rush that all first-time users experience. He liked it. Soon, he loved it. He kept doing it for 16 years while he developed into one of the premier pitchers in baseball. But six weeks ago, a dentist who was examining Schilling told him he should undergo a diagnostic biopsy. The dentist said Schilling might have cancer.

docs.abstract: R J Reynolds Tobacco Co document prepared in 1985 by outside lawyers hired to review cigarette maker's legal defenses indicates that company destroyed records and suppressed research about cancer hazards and other toxic effects of smoking; document is one of 39,000 internal tobacco company records released by House Commerce Committee on April 22 after lengthy fight by companies to keep them confidential (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: An R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company document prepared in 1985 by outside lawyers hired to review the cigarette maker's legal defenses indicates that the company destroyed records and suppressed research about the cancer hazards and other toxic effects of smoking. The document, which lawyers for R. J. Reynolds defended as a routine legal review, was one of 39,000 internal tobacco company records released yesterday by the House Commerce Committee, after a lengthy fight by the companies to keep them confidential. The committee subpoenaed the records after the judge in a Minnesota lawsuit against tobacco companies ruled that the documents contain potential evidence of fraud and other crimes by cigarette company executives and their lawyers.

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-10 Seoul Won't Press Japan On Compensation Issue South Korea said it would end its efforts to get compensation from Japan for South Korean women forced into Japanese military brothels in World War II and will instead pay the pensions itself. A3
